dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sparrow flutters in birdseed on a window sill. More bir crowd a bird feeder that hangs above.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lone child swings lazily on a swing. Other children tea about in a wild game of chase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on a piece of wood as it is fed through a wood chip

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man finishes feeding the log into the chipper. He pause wipe the sweat and grime from his face. He is WALTER, ear forties, features handsome but hardened by time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter is silhouetted by the early morning light. He hold duffel bag in his lap and watches out the bus window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun is just rising over the horizon, streaks of pink purple graze the frosted ground. Wilderness gives way to frozen farmland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter stands at a counter, a female officer fingerprints each finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter and some other men drop the side of the flatbed tr and trees crash to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus pulls away, revealing Walter standing alone on th sidewalk of a dilapidated neighborhood. He holds his duff bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The 5 o'clock whistle BLOWS. Workers hustle to get their coats and punch out. Walter stands in line, keeping to himself. As his turn arrives to punch out he receives a r knock by two guys play-fighting behind him. Walter doesn' react, punches out, and exits the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicki, a tough-looking but striking woman, stands in line little further back watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A superintendent opens the door to an apartment, then han Walter the keys. Her gaze is cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter closes the door and turns around. He stands in the middle of a prefab/pre-furnished kitchen, living room are Light works its way through the dilapidated blinds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter shakes the boss's hand -- BOB, early thirties, strapping and trim, is the manager of the business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARY-KAY, the secretary, looks up from her typing and tak Walter in. Bob introduces them. She is in her early forti Walter follows Bob from the office, Mary-Kay watches as t leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a flash as a camera snaps a photo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter is captured in a photograph, standing against a ba blue background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter lifts the blinds. The birds flutter away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter stands under the shower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter, hair wet and clean shaven, tosses back some pills

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tires SCREECH as cars tear out of the driveway. Walter st at a bus stop across the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Vicki walks across the lot, a car pulls up next to her men catcall and whistle out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicki flicks them off. The men burst into hysterics and p out of the lot. She gets in her Jeep and leaves, tearing the bus stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter looks after her then turns his collar up against t chill. It is late winter. The trees are bare -- black silhouettes against the darkening sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter turns towards the shelter for protection from the wind. Filling the kiosk, a clothing advertisement display young girl striking a seductive pose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on a police file. A mug shot reveals Walter, many y younger. Pages are flipped through giving glimpses of new clippings as well as typed documents. Words stand out -- "Convicted, 1st degree --," "3 counts --," "served --."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A plain clothes officer closes the folder and looks out h office window where Walter stands being fingerprinted. Th is Sergeant LUCAS, mid-fifties, face creased and greying hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter watches out the window as farmland gives way to ci Traffic builds, billboards line the highway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Details of machines cutting the wood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter fills the bird feeder with birdseed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is the SOUND of children playing, and Walter looks

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter's POV: Across the way, children play outside of th school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter watches then closes his window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter exits the police station and crosses the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on fingers typing on a keyboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A computer screen shows Walter's image -- the photo just taken of him against the blue background. Words appear ac the screen as they are typed, creating an Internet notification page:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Released: 02/25/02 Qualifying Offense(s):____________

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We MOVE in on the photo of Walter till it fills the frame

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FREEZE FRAME. All sound fades out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The title "THE WOODSMAN" fades in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter sits in a small windowless office with his coat st on. He looks at someone off screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So. How are you adjusting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm adjusting okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And your new apartment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Apartment's okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you taking your medication?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It gives me headaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you are taking it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Across from Walter, sits ROSEN, young, awkward and clearl new to the profession, jotting something down in a notepa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. I'll talk to your physician about the headaches. Maybe he can change the prescription.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter doesn't say anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROSEN (cont'd) And how's your job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The job's okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I take "okay" to mean you feel good about working there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said the job is okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) That's right, you did. pause) Have you made any friends there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not running for Mr. Popularity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) You seem a little hostile today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was a joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rosen jots something on his notepad. Walter reaches over taps on the notebook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WALTER (cont'd) It's called sarcasm, Dr. Rosen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No need to call me doctor. I'm a therapist, not a psychiatrist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rosen looks at Walter for a long moment. Walter avoids hi gaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter, I'd like you to try something for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like you to keep a journal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A diary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diaries have sent too many guys to prison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ev-i-dence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. It never crossed my mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was just an idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought a journal would encourage you to reflect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reflect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think reflection is good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's very good, indeed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By reflection we can derive a deeper meaning from our experience in life. We gain greater understanding about ourselves that can lead to making better choices in our relationships, our careers, and our goals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter looks at him flatly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You read that in a book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rosen blushes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No fucking way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then think about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter is silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sidewalk is crowded with pedestrians. Walter heads towards the pharmacy entrance, but he is abruptly cut off a group of kids zooming by on their scooters and skateboa He pauses for them to pass, watches after them momentaril then proceeds inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter hands a prescription to a MALE PHARMACIST. The pharmacist looks at the prescription. He glances at Walte then goes over to a FEMALE PHARMACIST working in the back area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She reads the prescription, glances at Walter over her bifocals, then back at the prescription. Walter has not missed any of this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There a problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A middle-aged shopper talking on her cell phone nearby lo over and pauses in her conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you read the prescription?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you fill the prescription?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I suggest one of you move your ass, because if I don't get my medication I get extremely violent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The male pharmacist scrambles to fill the prescription.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shopper gasps. Walter looks at her and smiles. The shopper stuffs her items in her cart and quickly leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter stifles his grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter opens the door to his apartment, carrying a grocer bag. As he flips on the lights, a metal object is thrown across the room. He catches it with one hand. It's a can beer. A man laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You still think fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carlos sits at the table with a six-pack. Walter sets the on the table and pops open the can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't need to think fast to handle beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ook some talking to convince your super I was a relative.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told her all my relatives are good-looking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carlos laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ, man, it's good to see you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carlos stands and they awkwardly embrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CARLOS (cont'd) You look good, damn good, considering you're an old man now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seems like the whole world's gotten younger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is silence. Carlos sits back down at the table and opens another beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter starts unpacking the groceries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You doing okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got a job at old Frank's place. His son runs it now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh man, that kid takes himself real serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, you still with Northland?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grins) Foreman now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beautiful. How's business?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Booming. Lots of building going on. We can't keep up with all the work. In fact, I just hired a few new guys...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glancing at Walter, he realizes his blunder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CARLOS (cont'd) Just until we catch up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a brief silence as both men drink. Carlos looks Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CARLOS (cont'd) I'll never forget you got me started there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just recommended you. You still had to prove yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carlos gets up and walks over to the window. He gazes outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, is that a school?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: K through sixth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carlos glances at Walter, then back outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Living across the street from a grade school. Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something wrong with that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just thinking of... the noise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like the noise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter walks over to the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WALTER (cont'd) One hundred and twenty feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Law says I can't come within one hundred feet of where children congregate. I figure the distance from my window to the school is one hundred and twenty. Make a bet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No way, man, you'd rob me blind!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men laugh, but the laughter quickly fades.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CARLOS (cont'd) But maybe it's not so healthy being so close, you know, to a school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (heated) You find me a decent place for under three hundred a month in this town, and I'll happily move out of this crap neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: arlos shrugs and tosses down the rest of his beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should go. Your sister worries, and when she worries she yells.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annette? She's good... tense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When can I see her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm working on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it because of Anna?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. She won't talk about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) You're the only one in the family who still talks to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember when they all referred to me as "the little spic poor Annette married." Except her brother. You treated me with respect. pause) Look, you paid your dues. Your slate is clean now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How old is Anna?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'll be twelve next week. We're throwing a big party on Saturday. Wish I could ask you to come...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only if it's no closer than a hundred feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carlos looks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WALTER (cont'd) Sorry, bad joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stiffly embrace. Then Carlos exits leaving Walter al

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOSE on a man's feet slowly walking heel to toe. The grou is covered in frost. TILT UP to reveal Walter counting hi footsteps as he walks towards the school across from his apartment building. The schoolyard is empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One hundred and ten, one hundred and eleven, one hundred and twelve...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bird's cry pierces the sky. Walter looks up to see a ha circling above. He watches for a moment then continues walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WALTER (cont'd) One hundred and thirteen, one hundred and fourteen, one hundred and fifteen...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches the school entrance and touches it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WALTER (cont'd) One hundred and twenty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter looks at the hawk still circling above and hollers

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WALTER (cont'd) How about that!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slowly the SOUND of children fades in and a red ball boun to Walter's feet. He looks in the direction the ball came from.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing is there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter looks back down at his feet. The ball is gone. The sound of children fades back away and is replaced by a rhythmic squeak. Walter looks towards the playground wher empty swing sways back and forth in the wind, the chain squeaking in its hinges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: he hawk's cry pierces the silence. Walter looks up to see the hawk being chased by two smaller birds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a tremendous crash as logs are dropped near the chipper. Forklifts move and stack wood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter stands at the end of a wood chipper, pushing a lon piece of wood through. Suddenly above the din of machiner there is the sound of raised voices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter looks across the way to see Vicki yelling furiousl and smacking a GUY around the head with her work gloves. man cowers, protecting his head from the blows. Some othe men nearby are doubled over in laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GOD DAMN IT! PEDRO! WHAT THE FUCK DO YOU THINK YOU ARE DOING! HOW WOULD YOU FEEL IF SOME FUCKER DID THAT TO YOUR SISTER?! YOU WOULDN'T THINK IT SO FUNNY THEN, WOULD YOU?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: he backs off out of breath. Pedro straightens up, having very hard time keeping a straight face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: he other guys start to applaud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicki looks around and storms off, kicking a piece of woo into one of the men, hard. She brushes past Walter on her to the exit. He watches after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicki sits alone at a table eating a sandwich. She takes large bites and eats fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter approaches carrying a tray of food. He pauses acro from where Vicki sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: icki ignores him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicki looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) Yeah, I'm fucking fantastic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter nods and keeps on walking. Vicki returns to her fo After a moment, she steals a glance up at Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Across the way, Mary-Kay watches Walter as he sits down t the table neighboring Vicki's.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Bob sits down across from Mary-Kay with a tray of food an newspaper. He opens the paper and starts to read.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, what'd he do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did who do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, the new guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob looks across the room at Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mind your own business, Mary-Kay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, just tell me what he did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob ignores her and reads the paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARY-KAY (cont'd) Drugs, armed robbery, manslaughter, tax evasion -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ob picks up his tray and moves away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary-Kay smiles to herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter sits on the bus. He is squeezed into the window se the bus crowded with commuters and teenagers on their way home from school. He focuses out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter sits alone on his couch, watching a baseball game, drinking a beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The winning run on base, and a full count on Williams, who's been in a terrible slump. Here's the pitch. Williams swings and misses! The Rangers win, ball game over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter switches off the TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter crosses the street outside of his apartment and he towards the bus stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: white Volvo is parked along the road. A MAN sits inside t car looking out towards the school. The engine is off. He in his twenties, good build, nice clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter looks at the man as he passes by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: he man doesn't notice him, his attention fixed down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter looks in the direction of his gaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: he schoolyard is quiet except for a couple of students running in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter looks back at the man. The man doesn't notice him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter hurries to his bus stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter works feeding wood through the chipper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: icki drives a forklift past Walter and watches him as she passes. He remains intent upon his work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter walks across the parking lot, heading towards the stop. Before he reaches the road Vicki's rusty old Jeep p up alongside him and stops, honking to grab his attention

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: icki rolls down the passenger side window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want a ride?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's fucking freezing out here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter hesitates and looks down the road. There is no bus sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VICKI (cont'd) Come on, I won't bite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they pull away, a beat up grey Chevy pulls into the parking lot. Sergeant Lucas gets out of the car, and paus watching after Vicki and Walter. He then turns and heads the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter and Vicki drive silently. Vicki glances at Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's something wrong with this picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What picture?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm talking about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter looks out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VICKI (cont'd) Here's this nice, hard working guy who suddenly appears out of the blue and rides the bus to and from work. I mean, who rides the bus anymore?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People without cars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gives him a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very weird.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No weirder than a sharp, young, good-looking woman working in a lumberyard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's weird about that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most women wouldn't choose it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess I'm not like most women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: icki takes out a cigarette and presses the cigarette ligh in, revealing a tattoo on her wrist of a pair of breasts angel wings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter notices the tattoo. Vicki notices Walter notice. S smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VICKI (cont'd) You're quiet at work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't hang out with the other guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neither do you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're all assholes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never spoke to me before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you were a dyke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicki laughs and stops at a red light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WALTER (cont'd) (smiling) Are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shoots him a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicki paces around the apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter takes two beers from the fridge then turns and sta holding them, watching her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Southern light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your windows face south. Northern light is the purest. But southern light is very good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll buy a plant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y ou should buy several. I've got shitty light in my place, but my plants don't seem to mind. Light's important, but it's not everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VICKI (cont'd) You plan to drink both those beers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter hands her a beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: What are you afraid will happen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not afraid. I'm just saying that Carlos has a thing for his daughter, and if he isn't careful he's going to suffer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you talked to Carlos about your concerns?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not that crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think you're crazy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I'm not, then what the hell am I doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you think you're here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know why. It's part of the parole deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that what you are angry about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talking to you is like riding on a merry-go-round.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is a marvelous image, Walter. Because by going in circles we find the things we missed the first time around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter looks at Rosen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long is this going to take?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (checking the clock) We have a few more minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, when will I be normal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) We have a lot of work to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (speaking slowly) Will I ever be normal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You couldn't say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what "normal" is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose it's however society defines it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you define it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then how do you know if your patients are getting better?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They usually tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do they know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is your idea of being normal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mimicking Rosen) What is your idea of being a Jew?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (controlled) Whatever my ideas are of being a Jew is not going to help you. looks at the clock) Why don't we continue this on Thursday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exploding) I want to be normal!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then go see a therapist who will tell you you're normal!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you, Rosen!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you're frustrated, Walter, but --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter gets up and slams out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: osen looks at the empty chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROSEN (cont'd) -- you really are making progress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter sits at his window with his journal, watching outs

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter's POV: Candy leans against his car, patiently wait Something grabs Candy's attention, and Walter follows his gaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kids pour off a school bus. Candy waves to one ANGEL-FACE BOY of ten or eleven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what should I do? Call the cops? he laughs) Yeah, that's pretty funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: he boy and a buddy run over to Candy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WALTER (V.0.) (cont'd) But what if Candy seduces one to go for a ride?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Candy smiles and offers Angel-face a candy bar, which the accepts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WALTER (V.O.)(cont'd) Yeah, that's right. If the boy goes for a ride it's because he wants to go for a ride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BELL rings. The other boy grabs Angel-face, and they off to school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter rests his chin on his hands, watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: icki closes her locker to see Walter standing at the end the room in front of his locker. She looks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter looks at her, closes his locker loudly, and walks brusquely past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicki stands near a pile of wood chips, taking a cigarett break.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter approaches, pushing a cart full of wood chips. Vic looks at him as if to say something, but Walter continues past, dumps the chips, and returns back inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter sits at a table across the room from Vicki.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ary-Kay enters and sits down with Walter

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Walter. How are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, it's really a beautiful day out there, and I was thinking -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter wipes his mouth and gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Got another load coming in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter exits. The smile fades from Mary-Kay's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: icki watches Walter leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter stands alone at the bus stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: icki gets in her Jeep and pauses before turning on the engine, watching Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns his back to the cold wind and her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicki turns on the car and pulls out of the lot, roaring Walter without looking at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicki moves around her apartment, cigarette in one hand, spray bottle in the other, squirting her plants.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She prunes dead leaves from one of them, then pauses look at the leaves in her hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't die on me, you little shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She aggressively squirts the little plant with water, the pauses, noticing her reflection in the window. She looks herself long and hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a knock on the door. Walter walks through the ro to the door, tucking in his shirt as he walks. He cracks door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicki stands outside. Walter opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to go for a ride?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter and Vicki drive without saying anything. Slowly th city-scape gives way to countryside. Walter looks over at Vicki. She stares ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter and Vicki get out of the car which is parked on th edge of a reservoir surrounded by a thick pine forest. Vi works her way down to the water's edge. A Great Blue Hero skims across the water's surface.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter watches her for a moment then follows. He sits dow near her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: icki lights a cigarette and stares out over the water. Af a long pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was prison like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) Y ou don't really --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes! I want to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter is quiet for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prison is... time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicki looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean the time you're locked away?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Prison is time. That's it. You think time, you feel time, you hear time. Your heart doesn't beat to live, it just beats... time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Don't be sorry for me. I did those things. No one else did. I'm dealing with that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicki looks out at the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father took me fishing here when I was a kid. He could name every fish in the lake. And for every fish he named, he had a fishing story. I hated fishing, but I loved his stories.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like a special guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father was an alcoholic who drank himself right into the grave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VICKI (cont'd) He said he couldn't help it. Said he hated himself for doing it. But, boy, did that man love to drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: here is a long pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've changed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why young girls, Walter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter is silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VICKI (cont'd) Is it their innocence? Their beauty?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) Their power. They seduce me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They seduce you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was always the one seduced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really believe that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (long pause) No. That's what I used to tell myself.   V

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what do you tell yourself now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. It's over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter looks at Vicki for a moment then stands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Then take me home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicki doesn't move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WALTER (cont'd) What do you want from me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicki stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to change my mind!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter is silent. Vicki shoves Walter hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VICKI (cont'd) Try, goddamnit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter stumbles back a few steps but regains himself. He stares at Vicki. His anger wells and he snaps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had this plan once... or maybe it was a dream. I was going to quit the building business... open my own shop. Make and design fine country furniture. I had saved enough money. I found the perfect place. Cheap five-year-lease. The loan was in the bag. My wife was a hundred percent behind it. Everything was set... Then I got in trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: pause) Do you know what the worst kind of trouble is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: icki watches Walter, silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WALTER (cont'd) It's trouble you bring on yourself... and the people you love the most. I lost a wife and a daughter. It hurt to lose my wife. It killed me to lose my daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter stops, looks at Vicki.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicki stares back at him. After a long pause, she approac and tentatively pulls him into an embrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close up on computer screen displaying a web page for registered felons. The heading reads -"Sex Offenders: the more we know, the better!" "Stay informed!" Mock Police sirens and lights frame the heading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: he listing of sex offenders scrolls down revealing photos name, address, and crime details of man after man, in alphabetical order, page after page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The scrolling slows down, past "Mason," past all of the Mc's..., and stops on "Miles, Walter." Convicted 1988 for sexual abuse of minors, five counts, released... It is th notification page that we saw created in the opening mont Walter's photo stares back at us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: e slowly pull back to reveal Mary-Kay at the computer. Sh clucks her tongue and shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicki and Walter lie in bed, spooning, fully clothed. Vic back to Walter, he holds her close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: gently) You know, this is crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Being here, with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) Most people say the odds are against me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What odds?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The percentages --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicki looks at him blankly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WALTER (cont'd) For men like me. They say most of us end up back... there. I'm saying there are risks... seeing me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, most people are stupid. pause) You want to talk about odds? One day I'll tell you how I survived as the youngest in a family of three sons. You wanna talk about odds?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not tell me now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long pause. Vicki lights a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got poked around... here and there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which brother did this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All three -- in chronological order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must hate your brothers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love my brothers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No you don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love all of them. They're strong, gentle men with families of their own. And if you asked them about what they did to me, they'd call you a fucking liar and then beat the shit out of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never asked them about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) Are you serious?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not ever?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not ever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: icki drinks from her beer. Walter watches her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter sits at his table, a scrap of wood in his hand. He whittles away at the wood. It is the rough outline of a h with wings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: here is a loud KNOCK on the door. Walter gets up. The KNO comes again, even harder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter goes to the door and opens it. The smiles fades fr his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ergeant Lucas pushes the door open further and walks righ in. He wears a well-tailored suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hiya, Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sergeant Lucas. (flashes his badge) May I come in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I am. But I always like to ask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter closes the door behind him. Lucas walks around the apartment. Walter watches him, uneasy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter hesitates, then obeys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LUCAS (cont'd) You don't know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you just tell me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucas walks over to the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WALTER (cont'd) (pause) I haven't broken any laws.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you won't mind if I look around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got something to hide?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't everybody?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could get a search warrant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you could, you would have brought one today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucas looks at Walter. He looks at the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cherry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unusual design for a contemporary piece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucas runs his hand along the surface.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not for sale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who said I wanted to buy it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucas walks back to the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LUCAS (cont'd) Two nights ago, a ten-year-old-girl was attacked not too far from here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LUCAS(cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Seems there's been a number of attacks on young girls in the vicinity. Kind of a coincidence, wouldn't you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter stands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you tell me when this happened --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter places his hands in his pockets. Lucas whirls arou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Move your fucking hands away from your pockets!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LUCAS (cont'd) Sit down!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LUCAS (cont'd) We know every step you make, every goddamn step! We know when you sleep, when you eat, when you shit, and when you jack off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucas leans over the table, nose to nose with Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LUCAS (cont'd) And when you sit by the window, watching the girls in the little cotton skirts parade by, do you wave your wanger at the girls? Is that when you jerk off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't talk to me like --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Like a piece of shit? In     my eyes, you are a piece of shit.     Think anyone would miss you if     I threw you out the window right     now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LUCAS(cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: I could say you jumped when I came in. Who are they going to believe? Not you, because you'd be a dead piece of shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat. Lucas taps Walter onL the forehead and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LUCAS (cont'd) (feigning kindness) We just want to make sure you're being a good boy, Walter. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter is silent. Lucas taps him again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LUCAS (cont'd) Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flatly) Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucas rises, spits his gum in the sink, and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter leans   over squeezing his head tight between his The sound of   children fades in and Walter looks up. The with the red   ball stands across from him in the doorway his bedroom.   She smiles and bounces the ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter folds over, cradling his head in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter stands alone at his bus stop. As he waits, he sees white Volvo turn a corner and pull up in front of the sch

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: he bus pulls up to the stop, obscuring Walter's view. He quickly gets on and moves to the back, looking for Candy' car. It is nowhere in sight, the place where it had parke empty. Walter sits down and stares ahead, numb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a bright Saturday afternoon. A city bus turns into t parking lot of a large mall. Passengers exit the bus and into the mall's entrance. Walter is among them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I followed a girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music blares from speakers. Packs of teenagers cruise the mall. It is alive with chatter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know why I did it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter is frequently jostled, as if he has forgotten how navigate crowds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WALTER (V.O.) (cont'd) There were all of these people...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: e passes many stores and snack shops then sees a Barnes & Noble and enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bookstore is two floors and vast. Walter looks lost a moves through the crowds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter rides an escalator. Three girls stand ahead of him The girl closest to him wears a short skirt which flutter above Walter's face. He looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was pretty. Very pretty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: hey reach the next level and Walter watches the girl walk away with her friends. Suddenly, the girl looks back. The eyes lock -- briefly. She W turns the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WALTER (V.O.) (cont'd) She gave me a look. If she hadn't given me that look...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter pauses, then follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl separates from her friends and goes down an aisl Walter follows her. She goes down another aisle. He follo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the middle of the aisle, the girl bends down, looking titles. From the end of the aisle, Walter pretends to be looking for a book as he edges closer to her. He's now a feet away. The girl pulls out a book and opens it. Walter gazes at the nape of her neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I help you find something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter turns, startled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind the salesman, Walter sees a security guard exit th rest room area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns, the girl is gone. He bolts the other way, throu the aisles, down the elevator, through the mall as fast a possible. The faces are a blur, sound becomes distorted. we hear --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did she know that you were following her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter sits in Rosen's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you think would happen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you want to happen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter is agitated. Rosen calmly writes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WALTER (cont'd) I can't believe I took such a risk. (looks at Rosen) Will you stop writing in that fucking pad!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rosen stops and looks at Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WALTER (cont'd) You know that if anything happens, I spend the rest of my life in prison. No parole, no nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this the first one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course it is! That's why I'm telling you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to calm down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With effort Walter settles down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROSEN (cont'd) You followed a girl. One girl. Perhaps you wanted to see what it felt like after so many years. Maybe unconsciously you were testing yourself. You followed her and nothing happened. And here you are talking about it with me. This is positive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a pause. Walter looks down, unconvinced. Rosen checks the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROSEN (cont'd) Walter, we'll pick up here next time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to talk about it now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll talk about it more on Thursday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember when you asked me what my idea of "normal" was?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently) Go home, Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I know. It's when I can see a girl, be near a girl, even talk to a girl... and walk away. (pause) That's my idea of being normal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter rides the bus, staring out the window. Sensing something, he looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A GIRL sits across from Walter. She is about twelve years old. She wears glasses and a pair of binoculars hangs aro her neck. She casually nibbles on food she produces from backpack. She glances at Walter briefly then looks back o the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter turns away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter and Vicki sit at his table eating Chinese take-out Walter glances at Vicki who is devouring her food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe this isn't a good idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) Us seeing each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks up at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neither am I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you should be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter gets up from the table and clears his plate to the sink. Vicki looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Walter, I got an idea of my own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He avoids her look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VICKI (cont'd) You listening to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VICKI (cont'd) We should live together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks at her) Live together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Move in with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a bad idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's a fucking good idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter goes to the fridge for a beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't even know how to live with myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just think about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got problems.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who doesn't?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most people don't have my kind of problems.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess that makes you pretty special.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not what I meant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicki looks at him blankly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WALTER (cont'd) I say we call it quits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: icki puts her fork down, pulls on her jacket and exits. Walter looks at the closed door, baffled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's gone. (pause) That was easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: e takes a swig from his beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WALTER (cont'd) Good. I'm glad. I'm fucking glad!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: W

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicki jogs down the stairs and over to her Jeep. She open the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter pulls the carving he was working on from a drawer looks at it. It's finished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicki reenters holding a plant and sets it loudly on the table. Walter looks at her then at the plant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: hat's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's it look like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets herself a beer from the fridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't need a plant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone needs a plant. This ivy is one tough baby. It's a cutting from one of mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter seems at a loss. Vicki takes a swig from her beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VICKI (cont'd) Here's the deal. Give it a little water. Go easy on the direct sunlight. And notice it every once in a while. They love it when you look at them, or touch their leaves. Can you handle that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter looks unconvinced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're such an asshole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She kisses him then gives him a teasing look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VICKI (cont'd) Don't be scared, Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cracking a smile) I'm not scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prove it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicki walks towards the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicki turns. He tosses her the carving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicki catches it and looks at it for a long moment, then Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WALTER (cont'd) I made it for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WALTER (cont'd) It's cedar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is the usual morning chaos in the locker room. Walt opens his locker but stops abruptly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: aped to the inside of his locker is a magazine ad of a yo girl, joyfully swinging on a swing. Scrawled over the ima in red marker is a circle with line across it and the wor "WE'RE WATCHING YOU" written below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter quickly tears down the picture and looks around. T men are all oblivious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter works at the saw, watching closely every person th walks by him. No one pays him any mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob, the boss, walks into the space and stops to have a f words with a worker who points in Walter's direction. Bob heads towards Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter sees him coming and pauses in his work. Bob walks right by to talk to another man working behind Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter watches for a moment then continues working.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter exits the mens room and stops to drink from the wa fountain. Mary-Kay is walking down the hall and pauses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Walter. How ya doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine thanks. How are you, Mary-Kay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leans up against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I've got this problem. I promised my sister that I'd baby- sit her little girl tonight while she's on a date. Single mother, right? Her daughter's a cute little thing, about nine or ten. Real entertaining. But once she's asleep, I get soo bored. I'd love to have some company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gives Walter a suggestive look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARY-KAY (cont'd) What are you doing tonight, Walter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cold) I got plans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A couple of men walk down the hall interrupting them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WALTER (cont'd) Have a nice day, Mary-Kay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter rides the bus, staring out the window. The bus is crowded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Iime passes, fewer passengers, dusk has turned to night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter and Rosen sit in their usual places.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're very late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't do it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said I was sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't move my patients around to accommodate one person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter silently stares at his hands. Rosen looks at him closely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROSEN (cont'd) Walter, I want to ask you a question. Will you try to answer it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROSEN (cont'd) When did it all start?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean my problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If by "problem" you mean your desire for prepubescent girls, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not a helpful answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's my answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rosen looks at Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: lose your eyes.

dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like you to close your eyes.

dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To relax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snaps) I'm relaxed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: H

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (closing his eyes) Okay. Eyes closed, mind a blank. I'm all yours. Do it, Rosen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rosen gets up so he's positioned directly in front of Wal

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I say the word "girl" what is the earliest image that you can remember?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. Can I open my eyes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. When I say the word "pretty," when I say the word "pleasure," what is the earliest memory you see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't see --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In your mind, Walter. Take your time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a moment, Walter's expression shifts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROSEN (cont'd) (watching closely) Who do you see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is she? What is she doing? ow old --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Not so fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. (pause) Where is she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In my bedroom, sleeping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In my bed, Rosen. Where do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In my bed too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're little kids.

dialogues.text: But roughly, how old?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A nap?

dialogues.text: Walter opens his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WALTER (cont'd) What the hell are you doing there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WALTER (cont'd) Don't ever do that again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like nobody behind my back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I shouldn't have been there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OSEN (cont'd) Walter, what did you do while taking a nap with your sister?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay I'll tell you what I did -- just to shut you up! (pause) I smelled her hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all. I just liked smelling her hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You felt pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (long pause) Yes.

dialogues.text: Rosen writes a few notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you get an erection?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glaring at Rosen) I was six years old!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I meant later... when you two took naps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter is silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROSEN (cont'd) When the two of you held each other. When you were ten or eleven and she was eight or nine. When your parents were out and the two of you were alone... completely alone in that big house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a small house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. A small house... with small rooms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (His eyes well up.) I smelled her hair. That's it. I just liked smelling her hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next week? The week after?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Early July.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: C'mon, Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not what you think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: D

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a long pause) I'm not a monster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a good man, Walter. Okay, you did some wrong things, but inside you're a good, decent man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I'm not a good man. Maybe inside I'm bad, and I'll always be bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: on't talk like that.

dialogues.text: The waitress interrupts to clear the table, leaning over grab the empty plates. Carlos checks her out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CARLOS (cont'd) (pause) Next week Annette is going away for a few days. And the thing is that when Annette's away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: arlos watches the waitress depart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CARLOS (cont'd) I get horny as hell for other women. (whispering) I mean I fantasize about raping some beautiful woman.

dialogues.text: You don't have to tell me this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just talking, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carlos, I never raped a woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. I'm just saying I understand.

dialogues.text: Walter doesn't look at Carlos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CARLOS (cont'd) It's crazy out there. (signaling to the crowd) Young girls wearing mini this and mini that. Sometimes when I walk down the street and pass some sexy- looking woman, she makes me feel like I'm bothering her. She stares down like she's afraid to look at me. Why she do that? Why can't she look me in the face?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see a pretty woman, I look. That's the price of beauty, my friend. My god, you should see what Anna's friends wear.

dialogues.text: arlos laughs. Walter looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carlos, can I ask you something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) N othing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ask me. Ask me anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) Did you ever... Do you have feelings for Anna?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: arlos looks at Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean... feelings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A look of horror/disgust passes over Carlos's face, and h lurches forward grabbing Walter by the shirt collar. Drin spill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, man. I don't got your sick problem, and if you or anybody else ever comes near my daughter, I'll kill you.

dialogues.text: Vicki stands before Walter who sits on the edge of the be Both are naked. She kisses him. He turns her around and p her to his lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter's hands are on her hips. He moves her body slowly very slowly -- around his lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicki goes with it, enjoying herself, then tries to turn around. Walter holds her still.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leans his face into her hair. He takes deep audible breaths. Vicki tries to turn again, but he won't let her. is aroused but confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VICKI (cont'd) Walter... let me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't touch me... please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: Walter lies in bed, eyes open. There is the SOUND of chil playing outside. He carefully sits up in bed revealing Vi asleep beside him.

dialogues.text: The boy gets in the car. Instant replay. The boy gets in car. ZOOM IN. The car door closes.

dialogues.text: icki walks into the room and sees Walter sitting by the window. She walks up behind him and puts her hands on his shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sneak up behind me like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your fucking problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why's it always my fucking problem?

dialogues.text: Vicki looks at Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicki looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WALTER (cont'd) I didn't sleep well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want to talk about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need a shower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks back into the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SCHOOL BELL rings and Vicki looks out the window. She s the children running into school. She looks back in the direction Walter left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicki and Walter ride in the car. Vicki glances at Walter stares ahead, then leans his head back and closes his eye

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl with binoculars comes to sit in the seat ahead o Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter stares at the girl. The bus pulls up to another st it is Walter's. The doors to the bus open. Walter looks a the doors, he does not move. The doors close. He looks ba at the girl. The bus drives on.

dialogues.text: The bus comes to a stop. The girl gets off amongst a coup of passengers. Walter follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl stands in the middle of the field looking at the through her binoculars. She turns slowly, scanning the tr She spots Walter and lowers the binoculars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter is silent. He looks up at the trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GIRL (cont'd) What are you looking at?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
